content: it's time for another good old-fashioned speed build
hey guys welcome back to another episode
of black magic craft this week I'm doing another speed build what am I making I'm
making the sweet mausoleum terrain to use in graveyard encounters is one of
the most useful things you can build as a crafting DM there are no shortage of
encounters that can take place in a graveyard it is such a classic
scenario such a good trope it's been quite some time since I built the dark
cathedral and the catacomb entrance so I figured it was time to put another
addition into my cemetery setup and I thought a perfect project both to add to
my collection and to tackle in a speed build
would be a little mausoleum it's a great project because it has a lot of nice
little details in it it's a building but it's also small enough that I could
tackle it in just a few hours well not quite a few hours to be honest this
build probably took me about six or seven hours because there are some
little finicky parts to it and some of the improvisation stuff I did on it
didn't really work out well and I had to redo things a few times but anyway it
was still totally built and finished and not that long and I think it will be a
nice inspiring little project for you guys before we jump over to the
workbench and I show you how I built this thing I just want to say thank you
to Frances for sending me this cool t-shirt much appreciated man I love it
all right enough taki talking more building building for the structure I
used foam core and you can see the sizes of the shapes that I cut it on the
screen here what's important to note is that I did not use the ready board brand
foam core from Dollar Tree where the paper peels off really easily because
I'd be applying a lot of glue and paint and washes to this structure I didn't
want something where the paper peeled off easily I wanted something really
nice and strong as a base for building so I used a different cheap foam core
board where the papered and peel off easily the stuff I used
here is from another dollar store Dollarama and it's still cheap but the
paper stays on really strong once I had the walls put together I just held them
up to another piece of foam cord to figure out the size of the roof pieces
cut those out and glued them into place I intentionally ran the second piece too
long so that I could then cut the appropriate angle off the excess with my
Olfa knife I wanted the mausoleum to have some really neat ornate details and
since I was pressed for time but also feeling lazy I figured it was the
perfect time to finally make use of some of these laser-cut and EF windows that I
got from shifting lands calm I had some concern that if I just glued these
straight to the paper on the foam core that the surface would look too smooth
when it came to painting so for the big front door I decided I wanted to texture
behind it and I did this by tracing out the shape of the laser-cut piece of MDF
and then I tried to peel off the paper a bit but this was the foam core that the
paper doesn't peel off very well so it peeled off some of it textured it a bit
with a tinfoil ball and that was just enough to roughen it up a bit then I
glued it in place using some regular white PVA glue I chose some smaller
arched windows to decorate the sides of the mausoleum I just equally spaced them
out and on these smaller ones I didn't bother trying to texture behind them I
didn't think it would make much of a difference I added one last little
detail using a little ornate circle window to the front of the building I
decided that I wanted to do the stone frame of the front door out of one
single piece of foam so using another of the same MDF window I traced out the
shape with a extended border thickness and I cut that out on my procs on table
I then used the actual MDF window as a jig to cut out the inner circle once I
had that shape I shaved it down to a thin piece of material and drew on some
grout lines this gave me my stone are frame for the smaller windows I found it
easier to just cut some thin strips of XPS foam and hold the MDF window in
place and just cut out around it using my exacto knife and they did the same
thing for the circular window as well I did all the brickwork using the same
technique that I use on a lot of my builds you've seen me do it on the
bridge tutorial in the dark cathedral built a whole bunch of others basically
it's just a bunch of thin strips of XPS foam that I then cut up into various
Heights and I just glue in place for the corners I just bend these thin little
bricks and offset them from side to side so it looks like interlocking thick
bricks I go all the way around the building until all walls are complete
and when I do stuff like the roof Peaks I just run all the bricks wild I don't
worry about cutting little tiny pieces and I just run them oversized
let the glue dry and then with a exacto knife or an Olfa knife I just cut off
the excess and that way I have a perfect line really easily I wanted to do a
copper roof on this piece so I wasn't gonna be laying a bunch of shingles I
was gonna be using the flat surface of the actual foam core for most of the
roof but I needed some border pieces to hide all of the edges and I decided that
I wanted these to be triangular so I cut some small strips of XPS foam on my
props on table and then using this angle cutter from shifting Lance com I was
able to bisect these strips and create two little triangular wedges that I
could use to cap off the roof I glued these in place freehand mitered
all the connections until I had all of the ridges covered I wanted to do some
metal banding on the roof so I took some construction paper and I chose pink to
match the foam because I thought that was fun and using my paper cutter I
cut some narrow strips of paper I then glued these in place using a glue stick
this is a really clean and easy way to apply construction paper strips to a
building I covered all the appropriate seams and did three strips up the main
area of the roof I used one continuous piece to do both sides to simulate
rivets I used these tiny little gems that I got from Michaels and super glued
them in place on all of the joints on the banding I could finally give this
thing a coat of my black magic base coat that's the mix of Mod Podge and black
paint to stiffen up all of the styrofoam this piece had a lot of deep little
nooks and crannies that the Mod Podge didn't get into so I actually did end up
giving this a second coating of watered-down black paint I did a really
basic speed build paint job on this all the stonework just got a dark gray a dry
brushing of a medium gray and then a dry brushing of a light gray and a final
very very light dry brushing of an off-white it wasn't until the roof that
the paint job got kind of interesting when I had to simulate the weathered
copper roof I mixed together this kind of lime green and aqua blue color to get
that nice aged copper look and this took a few coats until the black was
completely covered originally I planned for all of the window features to look
like stone but I realized that they looked way too flat and kind of weird so
I decided to paint them out in a bronze metallic they stood out a little bit too
much so I decided to give them a light dry brushing of that same green to give
them that weathered effect as well and then it was time for the black wash and
this is where I was really hoping it would save me because that roof was
looking way too bright for my tastes and in the back of my head I was thinking
okay the wash is gonna tone it and it's gonna make it look great the
problem is that the black wash really looked very streaky on it no matter what
I did and looked kind of dirty and really didn't turn out quite the way I
had hoped in retrospect I should have painted that roof with that bronze color
first and then covered it in the green in a kind of stiffled effect so it
wasn't so extreme maybe but this is where I was with it so I just kept going
back and forth between doing a little bit of wash putting back on a bit of
green rubbing it doing different things until I got it to a point where I was
happy with it but really I had a hard time getting it to either not look like
it just had black paint slapped on it or was like this glowing aqua green color
eventually I got it to a point where I was okay with it though the last thing I
did to complete this paint job was to stipple on a little bit of an olive
green to create a bit of a mossy kind of effect around the bottom of the
stonework after everything was totally dry I gave it a nice coat of Minwax
polyurethane this helps to seal and protect both the paint and the foam and
make the piece a little bit more rigid and durable so it will last me a long
time I think I could have done a much better paint job on this piece but by
the end of it I was starting to rush and just trying to get it done that being
said even with a very basic paint job it's still gonna look pretty good on my
game table and serve its function perfectly items from shifting lance comm
played a big part in this build the windows added a really fast decorative
feature and the jig's for my Crocs on allowed me to do some cuts that I
normally would not have been able to do otherwise I am NOT sponsored by shifting
lance comm Gerrard is just a guy consider a friend and I think he makes
really great products and I love using them so if you want to pick some of
those up head on over to shifting Lance comm to check them out he's got way more
tools than I've actually used on this channel of course if you want to pick up
any of the other tools and supplies that I use in my builds you can head on over
to black magic craft OCA where I have my essential equipments
or with links to Amazon for all of the things that I use and recommend those
sales give me a small commission that helped fund these videos the other way
these videos are funded is by the generous support of people on patreon if
you love what I do and you want to help me to continue serving the community the
best way you can do that is by supporting me on patreon check out the
page and see the rewards that you get for your support well guys I hope you
found this video enjoyable and inspiring if you build your own cool little
mausoleum for your cemetery encounters I'd love to see them head on over to the
tabletop crafters guilt and post some photos of your build there of course if
you found this video useful hit that like button and drop me a comment below
and if you're new to the channel hit subscribe I got a ton of cool videos of
other neat builds for your tabletop role-playing games until next week guys
Cheers happy crafting and happy gaming
